target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">.</a></strong></h2>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d966d8de94e8657cd26713f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Hotel Reviews Banner first impression\" height=\"151\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d1aaf7ffa48002894d231?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Islander Resort entrance\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The soothing fountain at the front of the Islander Resort is the first thing visitors see after stopping to check in at the guard house.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jen Karetnick/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>A marquee sign on the west side of the Overseas Highway alerted my husband and me to the presence of <a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">the resort</a> and <a href=\"https://www.islanderfloridakeys.com/florida-keys-history-discovery-center/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The Florida Keys History &#38; Discovery Center</a>, a museum-aquarium (and more) that's located on-site.</p><p>We pulled in and stopped at the guardhouse, where masked employees reminded us about COVID-19 policies and directed us to the lobby. There, we could clearly see the plexiglass-wrapped valet station, whose use had been discontinued.</p>\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d1ae07ffa48002894d232?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Islander Resort Lobby\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Only five people are allowed in the lobby at one time. Masks are mandatory wherever there is a roof overhead.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jen Karetnick/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Because we were pulling up as a storm was pushing out, the fountain that usually greets travelers wasn't on. Only five people are allowed in the lobby at one time, but we arrived at a slow time in the early evening and were the only ones checking in.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">The property's</a> 24 acres have been recently reimagined with native plants and renovated rooms.&#160;</p><p>My husband, a physician who is practiced at personal protection, went inside while I stayed outside to minimize exposure. Both he and the desk attendant wore masks, and he sanitized his hands after he came outside.&#160;</p>\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d1e2f60bf1f002807978f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Islander Resort Beach w COVID sign\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The hotel had clearly marked public areas with signage for coronavirus policies.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jen Karetnick/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>We were immediately relieved at how clearly <a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">the hotel</a> had marked the beach, pool, and pier areas for coronavirus policies. There were very few staff and guests walking around, and the ones that were used masks.&#160;</p><p>Later, after dinner, the beach had more of a throng, with some folks playing with their children and/or dogs, and many had mask-less faces. Technically, because this was open air, it was legal. But because people were gathering in groups on the beach and pier, we decided to leave.</p>\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d979264d831b2141f07abd1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"2 Hotel Reviews Banner The room\" height=\"151\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d1b5160bf1f002807977e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Islander Resort kitchen area\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A full-size refrigerator and microwave makes traveling with families, pets, and picky eaters a lot easier.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jen Karetnick/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>We booked a standard, single-story <a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html%23availability\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Tropical View King room</a> that opened onto the parking lot.</p><p>The rooms are a generous 370 square feet, and the access and views get better from there, opening onto the beach, with or without an ocean view. Our friends who traveled to the hotel for the same weekend booked earlier and stayed in a villa-style beachside suite with two separate rooms. It was also about the same size. Suite views are variable, ranging from courtyard to ocean, but the size can blossom up to 1,070 square feet for a two-bedroom.&#160;</p><p>Although our single-story, motel-style Tropical View King room was standard, it felt large with a kitchen with a full-size refrigerator, coffee fixings, and a microwave. It struck me as especially handy for families and longer-term stays.&#160;</p><p>There was also a closet &#8212; more like a wardrobe &#8212; and the bureau aligned with that, which was where the 50\" smart TV sat.&#160;</p>\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d1cbf60bf1f0028079784?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Islander Resort Steam Shower and Toilet\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The bathroom is small but clean, and little touches went a long way.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jen Karetnick/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>A small bathroom was clean and updated with a steam shower. I appreciated how nicely the towels were folded, and the large-format Paul Mitchell bath amenities felt like an indulgence. Everything was visibly clean.</p><p>The sink, however, is on the outside of the bathroom, across from the little kitchen area. This made the entrance way a little tight. There's not a lot of space to unpack toiletries, either.</p>\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d1c3b7ffa48002894d239?format=jpeg\" alt=\"hotel room\" height=\"900\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A standard guest room offers plenty of space for two and includes a screened lanai.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jen Karetnick/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>The King-sized bed, covered in blue-and-white linens, took up about half the room. I loved how wide the bed was, and my husband appreciated the firm mattress. With plantation shutters keeping out the sun and good, strong air-conditioning, the room was a comfortable place to hang out, day or night. We knew we had left our anxieties at home when we gave in to the urge for a late afternoon nap.</p><p>The rest of the space was comprised of a small table that could serve as a desk or a spot to dine, plus a love seat. A door at the end of the room opened to a screened porch with patio furniture and a ceiling fan to cut the humidity. When we weren't sleeping or in the water, we hung out on the terrace, sipping wine we brought and chilled in the fridge, or reading under the fan's lazy breeze.</p><p>While I found the heavy, dark furniture dated and out of its tropical element, the tile floor, sea-themed artwork, and blue-and-green color scheme lightened up the room.</p><p>With modern minimalist design, it was hard to tell if anything extraneous had been removed for the sake of COVID. Robes hung in the wardrobe (slippers aren't supplied regardless), and two decorative pillows rested on the love seat. While no paper flyers for activities, magazines, or menus were in the room, the sugar and creamer were filled for a few days' stay.</p><p>In fact, staying at <a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">the resort</a> didn't feel much different than it did before the pandemic, aside from the obvious design updates. While I was nervous prior to arrival, once I entered the room I felt fine. The obvious cleanliness helped, and the privacy was reassuring. We couldn't hear anything from neighbors, and doors, which you approach from outside, were far enough apart that even if people weren't wearing masks, we didn't&#160;come within six feet of each other.&#160;</p><p>As a bonus, while I usually find it difficult to sleep in a hotel the first night, the pandemic has had the opposite effect on me. Staying at <a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">the Islander</a> was the only time I've felt rested since February.</p><p>Still, while I enjoyed my stay &#8212; and clearly needed a change of scenery &#8212; I would have been uneasy had it been at full capacity. Another friend who went for a long weekend after I returned reported staff wearing inefficient neck gaiters, no visible cleaning, and too-crowded pools. I'd return, but if the pandemic is still raging, only during weekdays in the low season.&#160;</p><p>I'd also upgrade to a suite with a beachside view, which can cost about $120 more for a room that is roughly the same size as mine, with a much better vantage point. The view determines the price, with rooms and <a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow sponsored\">beachside suites</a> on the ocean side (where we were staying) starting at $189 and <a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow sponsored\">townhouses on the bayside</a> at $260.&#160;</p><p>Prices rise in peak season and mandatory minimum stays are often required. But if you book early enough, you might be able to score a standard room with a beach view for a nominal extra charge.</p><h2>Compare room types and prices for <a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html%23availability\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored nofollow sponsored\">Islander Resort</a></h2>\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d966d8de94e8657cd267145?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Hotel Reviews Banner On site amenities\" height=\"151\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d1d7260bf1f0028079788?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Islander Resort Saltwater Pool\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The saltwater pool close to the bar is &#34;unofficially&#34; the adult pool, although children are welcome. You might have to remind them about social distancing, as parents and staff both don&#39;t keep an eye out.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jen Karetnick/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Islander Resort</a> always reminds me of the lyrics of the old Madonna song, \"La Isla Bonita.\" Whenever I'm there, lounging at one of the saltwater pools, I think of how the sun really does seem to perch higher in the sky, with pink-and-gold sunsets lasting as long as it takes to savor a frozen pi&#241;a colada, which the bar makes with actual coconut.&#160;</p><p>Despite my desire to rhapsodize it, however, <a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Islander Resort</a> is just as much a good-time Jimmy Buffet tune as it is a soothing Spanish lullaby. The pools can be quiet and peaceful or occupied by interconnected family groups and occasionally rowdy tourists who don't control their children.&#160;</p><p>Several times, we had to remind children about maintaining their distance from us, at which point they'd swim closer on purpose and mock us.</p><p>I also saw a young boy do a front somersault into the pool, which has a depth of four feet. Neither the pool staff, who wear neck gaiter and bandanas as opposed to masks, nor beer-in-hand parents do a good job of watching for danger.&#160;</p><p>It's worth noting that masks aren't required for guests at the pool, but wristbands are. You'll be stopped at the gate and asked for your room number, then handed a towel.</p><p>As a mom of two and a former teacher of 15 years, I found it irritating to take matters into my own hands. But given the number of adults who won't follow guidelines, it was not entirely surprising. At the end of the day, I also had to consider where I was: The Conch Republic, where everyone is in a Sovereign State of Mind (this is the Keys' actual motto) and everything is laissez-faire. Even during a pandemic, you're apparently expected to roll with it.&#160;&#160;</p><p>And, it should be noted, the beach lounges and cabanas were completely deserted, and lounge chairs at both pool and the beach were grouped and rearranged to provide maximum separation.</p><p>Hanging out on the sand was a wiser decision, albeit a hotter one. Plus, taking a socially distanced stroll on the beach, pier, and grounds, day or night, was a nice change of pace from walking around the same neighborhood block at home.</p><p>Still, make sure you inspect the beach towels, which were handed out at the pool. Despite the claims of a costly renovation, we found several stained beyond repair, visible even when rolled up in the bin. And though I handed one back to an attendant and mentioned that it looked so bad that it should be taken out of circulation, I saw her throw it in the dirty towel bin.</p>\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d1edf7ffa48002894d250?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Islander Resort Directional Signs\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Masks aren&#39;t required for guests at the pool, but wristbands are. You&#39;ll be stopped at the gate and asked for your room number, then handed a towel.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jen Karetnick/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>In regular times, activities include full moon yoga, Bingo, kids' craft sessions, movie night, and more. However, <a href=\"https://www.islanderfloridakeys.com/resort-activities/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">resort activities</a> have been suspended until further notice. You can still fish off the pier, however.</p><p>In addition, you can use kayaks, paddleboards, and water bicycles. The guidelines for use are one hour per person per day, which is covered by a $30 daily resort fee. We thought we would take advantage of this, but the days were too hot to engage in exercise. Given that swimming and water sports are the only activities available, management might also want to rethink charging such a steep resort fee, especially since some of the resort's facilities are closed.&#160;</p><p>For instance, Elements Lounge &#38; Fine Dining was not in operation. Instead, Tides Beachside Bar &#38; Grill was open for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Much of the fare was refreshing, well-prepared, and evocative of the region. We felt fine lunching on a less-crowded mid-afternoon, but a strict noon rush kept us in a suddenly abandoned pool instead.</p><p>While things seemed clean, we didn't see any increased sanitization going on aside from the staff wiping down tables at the restaurant.</p><p>You can also place orders to go and get ice cream at a pick-up window framed by plexiglass. But because this also seemed to be where waiters picked up drinks and orders to serve at the pool, we chose not to compete for the same air space.</p>\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d1fac7ffa48002894d259?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Islander Resort fishing pier without sign\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>In regular times, activities are a-plenty at Islander Resort. During the pandemic, some are suspended, but water sports equipment are included with the resort fee.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jen Karetnick/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>In addition to swimming, many South Floridians like to <a href=\"https://www.islanderfloridakeys.com/boats-trailers/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">bring down their boats</a> and get out on the water all day; others like to arrange charters and water sports rentals through <a href=\"https://www.islanderfloridakeys.com/islander-girl-tours/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Islander Girl Tours</a>, which is an independent company that leaves from a site on the hotel grounds.</p><p>If you bring back a catch from the fishing pier or a day on the boat, <a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Islander Resort</a> will also rent propane gas grills for $75 per day and include grilling utensils. They usually place them behind the screened lanais. Contact Guest Services for availability.</p>\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d966d8ee94e8657cd267149?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Hotel Reviews Banner What&#39;s nearby\" height=\"151\" width=\"1201\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Islamorada is filled with well-known restaurants, bars, and attractions, including the famous, multi-level <a href=\"https://www.holidayisle.com/florida-keys-restaurants/holiday-isle-tiki-bar\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Holiday Isle Tiki Bar</a>. We dined at two favorites: <a href=\"https://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/6415797/type/dlg/https://www.tripadvisor.com/Restaurant_Review-g34346-d1071834-Reviews-Ziggie_Mad_Dog_s-Islamorada_Florida_Keys_Florida.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Ziggie &#38; Mad Dog's</a> for some absolutely terrific steaks, and <a href=\"https://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/6415797/type/dlg/https://www.tripadvisor.com/Restaurant_Review-g34346-d1342990-Reviews-Lazy_Days-Islamorada_Florida_Keys_Florida.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Lazy Days Restaurant</a> for seafood. At Lazy Days, you can request for them to cook your catch, and you can also watch the sunset from the beach. We caught the tail end of a pink sky as we dined, having stopped first at <a href=\"https://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/6415797/type/dlg/https://www.tripadvisor.com/Restaurant_Review-g34346-d500193-Reviews-Pierre_s-Islamorada_Florida_Keys_Florida.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Pierre's Restaurant and Beach Caf&#233;</a> at Morada Bay.</p><p>Islamorada is called the \"Sportfishing Capital of the World,\" and you can charter a fishing expedition through the hotel or <a href=\"https://islamoradachamber.com/fishing-marinas/%23!directory/map/ord=rnd\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">with any number of reputable outfits</a>. If you'd rather learn about dolphins, stingrays, sea turtles, and alligators, stop into <a href=\"https://theaterofthesea.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Theater of the Sea</a>, which also has some gorgeous gardens. For a different kind of beauty, go birding and hiking at <a href=\"https://www.floridastateparks.org/WindleyKey\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Windley Key Fossil Reef Geological State Park</a>.&#160;</p><p>Thanks to the COVID-19 pandemic, park hours and facilities have changed, so be sure to visit the website before you go. Masks are required inside any covered areas at Theater of the Sea and other similar attractions, even if most of it is outside.</p><p>And Islamorada's many food-and-drink establishments seem as busy as they are during high season, in part because Monroe County's government (as opposed to its citizens) has been very strict about hotel and restaurant occupancies. It looks like they're overflowing, with waits for dinner, when they really just have less, socially distanced room to host visitors. I recommend making reservations even if you think you don't need them, even if you've been to places in the past where you haven't required them.</p><p>Also keep in mind that while masks are mandatory, the folks who live in the Keys are used to doing what they please. Big government is not their kind of thing. Thus masking is not something a lot of them willingly follow.&#160;</p><h2><a href=\"https://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/6415797/type/dlg/https://www.expedia.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored\">Check flight prices to Florida on Expedia</a></h2>\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d966d8ee94e8657cd26714a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Hotel Reviews Banner What others say\" height=\"151\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Islander Resort has a <a href=\"https://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/6415797/type/dlg/https://www.tripadvisor.com/Hotel_Review-g34346-d231957-Reviews-Islander_Resort-Islamorada_Florida_Keys_Florida.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">4.5 rating on Trip Advisor</a> and a 9.4 out of 10 on <a href=\"https://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/6415797/type/dlg/https://www.hotels.com/ho172823/?\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Hotels.com</a>, where guests often comment about the unusual beauty of the wide, shady beach, the exceptional landscaping, and the comfort of the rooms with porches or screened lanais.&#160;</p><p>Guests also praise the amenities, which range from ping pong to fishing to kayaking. Families love that there's plenty to do, including visiting the on-site Florida Keys History &#38; Discovery Center, a museum-aquarium-movie theater about nature.</p><p>Some register complaints about the tight bathrooms, which are small but updated with steam showers. A few others feel that the mattresses are hard and that the beach sand is not as white as they might prefer. And recently, a couple of guests noted that the staff hasn't been responsive to their needs, but the current situation is certainly straining resources.</p><h2><a href=\"https://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/6415797/type/dlg/https://www.tripadvisor.com/Hotel_Review-g34346-d231957-Reviews-Islander_Resort-Islamorada_Florida_Keys_Florida.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Read reviews, compare prices, and book Islander Resort on Trip Advisor</a></h2>\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d966d8ee94e8657cd26714b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Hotel Reviews Banner What you need to know\" height=\"151\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Who stays here:</strong>&#160;Families, couples, and people who like to spend time on the water boating, fishing, and paddling (one hour per person, per day, included with resort fee).</p><p><strong>Yes, even during COVID: </strong>As mentioned, many tourists and families are still visiting, and not keen to follow all the policies. We also noticed a lot of mask gaiters and bandanas in lieu of real masks, especially on waitstaff and pool attendants. The material was flimsy and fell off when they spoke; noses weren't covered; and had we not been dining outside, we would have left a couple of establishments.</p><p><strong>We like:</strong>&#160;The long, wide beach and fishing pier, both of which offer pleasant ways to spend time in solitude.</p><p><strong>We love (don't miss this feature!):</strong> The on-site <a href=\"https://www.keysdiscovery.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Florida Keys History &#38; Discovery Center</a> is a museum, lecture hall, movie theater, research library, and more. Run by the non-profit Florida Keys History and Discovery Foundation, it recently added aquariums and interactive exhibits from the Mote Marine Laboratory's Coral Reef Exploration.</p><p><strong>We think you should know:</strong>&#160;While Monroe County has a mandatory mask policy, the community here is highly independent and doesn't like being told what to do. You'll find a lot of waitstaff wearing their fishing neck gaiters, which continuously fall down when they talk and are not a good substitute for masks.</p><p><strong>We'd do this differently next time:</strong> Instead of competing for a table in reduced-occupancy dining rooms or eating outside in the heat and humidity, I'd do more take out and eat on the screened-in porch and take advantage of my room's kitchen.</p>\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f1f2225aee6a822c9029ff4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Hotel Reviews Banner COVID 19 policies\" height=\"418\" width=\"3335\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>The <a href=\"https://www.islanderfloridakeys.com/policies-procedures-guidelines/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">policies at Islander Resort</a> dovetail with Monroe County in general. Face coverings over both mouth and nose must be worn in public whenever there is a roof overhead. That includes the <a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Islander Resort</a> lobby, where there is a maximum of five guests allowed at one time.</p><p>In addition, the following safety measures have been taken:</p><ul><li>Signage advising guests of social distancing and other policies is frequent throughout the property.</li><li>Hand sanitizers are available throughout the property, but there could be more.</li><li>Groups of lounge chairs at the pool and beach have been removed and rearranged to reflect the recommended six feet of social distance.</li><li>Dedicated pool attendants distribute wrist bands and pool towels, but the station was abandoned many times during the day, and we walked in without wrist bands on our second day there; we eventually were chased down and handed them.</li><li>Guest rooms are sanitized prior to arrival and housekeepers will only enter to clean every three days.</li><li>The pool, splash pad, beach, and pier are all open to overnight guests only, although the splash pad was closed when we were there.</li><li>Key card and high touch surfaces are continually sanitized, according to the website, but we didn't see any cleaning going on aside from the staff wiping down tables at the restaurant.</li></ul>\n\t\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e27582662fa8110bc34a994?format=jpeg\" alt=\"7 Hotel Reviews Banner Bottom Line\" height=\"151\" width=\"1201\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>With children returning to (mostly virtual) school, stress and anxiety levels &#8212; along with virus levels &#8212; are ramping up again. For South Florida locals, <a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Islander Resort</a> in Islamorada is a good option to decompress for a socially distanced weekend. But if you're not from the area, please strongly consider waiting to visit until it's safer to do so.</p><p>For out-of-state travelers, please follow state, CDC, and WHO guidelines about where and when to safely visit Florida. As a state, we depend on tourism. The <a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Islander Resort</a> is a good value with the perfect Keys vibe that is ideal for groups of travelers, and its recent upgrades have made the grounds enchanting. The in-room kitchen also allows you to tend to picky family members, long-term stays, and for those that want to take out food rather than eat at restaurants.&#160;</p><p>But you do need to watch the pool and beach public areas, which can become dense at times with people, especially children, not keeping enough distance. The staff doesn't pay attention to that, although you can see why. They're stretched thin, and it didn't look like some of them were happy to be working in the hospitality industry.</p><p>Still, the bandanas and neck gaiters they're wearing are simply not good enough, although since they're outside, we felt it was safer than it would have been. I also recommend a few more sanitizing stations placed around the property, or stockpiling your own, and would like to see more actual cleaning of high-touch surfaces, not just paying lip service to cleaning.</p><p>Crowded public spaces, lack of attention to guests breaking social distancing rules, staff members themselves not practicing the best mask policies, and not enough visible cleaning might give you pause, though, if you're high-risk or ultra-cautious.&#160;</p><p>But the positives outweighed the negatives, and for the sake of my mental health, I'd personally return to the <a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Islander</a> and places like it during the pandemic at low-volume times, such as early autumn weekdays while kids are in school. Unless they lock it down again, Monroe County hasn't seen the last of me.&#160;</p><h2><a href=\"https://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6776&#38;awinaffid=257137&#38;clickref=&#38;ued=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.booking.com%2Fhotel%2Fus%2Fislander-resort.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Book Islander Resort starting at $189 per night here</a></h2>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 10:18:03","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:18:03","title":"Robinhood, TDAmeritrade, and other online stock-trading platforms all experienced issues on Monday","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/robinhood-tdameritrade-schwab-vanguard-stock-trading-site-app-issues-monday-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f198f95191824285157902a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"TD Ameritrade\" height=\"1672\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A pedestrian walks by a TD Ameritrade office on November 25, 2019 in San Francisco, California.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Justin Sullivan/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>Robinhood, TDAmeritrade, Schwab, and Vanguard all experienced issues on Monday.</li><li>In many instances, users reported problems logging into their accounts, placing trades, or having them executed.&#160;</li><li>Short outages are typical, though a sustained, industry-wide issue is rare.&#160;</li><li>Also on Monday, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/robinhood-sec-finra-investigation-march-trading-service-outage-stock-brokerage-2020-8-1029548651#\">Bloomberg reported</a> Robinhood was being investigated by US authorities over an outage it experienced earlier this year. A spokesperson declined to comment on the report.&#160;</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>Several major online brokerages and trading platforms were rocked by service interruptions during trading Monday.</p><p>Robinhood, TDAmeritrade, Charles Schwab, and Vanguard all said they had experienced some form of issues or slowness on their websites.</p><p>Robinhood, the extremely popular online brokerage, said its issues were resolved around 12 p.m. Eastern after customers logged thousands of reports beginning shortly after 8 a.m through the opening of trading.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Robinhood Help  (@AskRobinhood) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1300466229384110082?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">August 31, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p><p>TDAmeritrade <a href=\"https://twitter.com/TDAmeritrade/status/1300501938493153280\">said</a> that many of its clients had experienced \"high levels of slowness\" on its web platforms affecting logins. The issues have been fixed, it said.</p><p>Schwab and Vanguard <a href=\"https://twitter.com/CharlesSchwab/status/1300456866548510722\">also</a> <a href=\"https://twitter.com/Vanguard_Group/status/1300440019178532870\">said</a> they were experiencing issues Monday, and by late afternoon not yet said they were resolved.</p><p>Discrete outages are common for online brokerages, if not many websites across the web. However, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-08-31/robinhood-reports-trading-problems-is-working-to-resolve-them?sref=LspfQlRv\">as Bloomberg points out,</a> a coinciding outage is rare. <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/robinhood-sec-finra-investigation-march-trading-service-outage-stock-brokerage-2020-8-1029548651\">According to the news site,</a> the US Securities and Exchange Commission as well as an industry self-regulatory body are investigating another major outage experienced by Robinhood earlier this year. A spokesperson <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/robinhood-sec-finra-investigation-march-trading-service-outage-stock-brokerage-2020-8-1029548651\">declined to comment</a> on the reported investigations.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 10:18:03","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:18:03","title":"A US Navy E-2C Hawkeye crashed in Virginia, but the crew managed to bail out safely","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-navy-e-2c-hawkeye-crashes-in-virginia-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d6ba660bf1f002807997c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"An E-2C Hawkeye prepares to land on the flight deck aboard the aircraft carrier USS John C. Stennis (CVN 74) in the Atlantic Ocean\" height=\"366\" width=\"733\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An E-2C Hawkeye prepares to land on the flight deck aboard the aircraft carrier USS John C. Stennis (CVN 74) in the Atlantic Ocean.\n<p class=\"copyright\">U.S. Navy photo by Mass Communication Specialist 3rd Class Skyler Okerman</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>A US Navy E-2C Hawkeye airborne early warning and control aircraft crashed in Virginia on Monday, a Naval Air Forces Atlantic spokesperson told Insider in an emailed statement.</li><li>The four-man crew was able to bail out of the aircraft safely.</li><li>The Navy says that initial reports indicate their were no structural damages or injuries to people on the ground caused by the crash, which is currently under investigation.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>A US Navy plane crashed in Virginia Monday afternoon, Naval Air Forces Atlantic spokeswoman Cmdr. Jennifer Cragg told Insider in a statement.</p><p>The plane, an E-2C Hawkeye airborne early warning and control aircraft assigned to Airborne Command &#38; Control Squadron (VAW) 120 Fleet Replacement Squadron at Naval Station Norfolk, crashed in Accomack County, Virginia just before 4 pm.</p><p>The plane was conducting a training flight at the time of the incident.</p><p>The crew, which consisted of two pilots and two other crewmembers, was able to safely bail out of the aircraft and was recovered. The pilots and aircrew are required to wear parachutes in the aircraft. AIRLANT says that initial reports indicate that the crash did not cause any damage to structures or harm to anyone on the ground.</p><p>The Navy says the cause of the crash is currently under investigation.</p><p>The E-2C Hawkeye is an all-weather, twin-turboprop aircraft and an important part of the carrier air wing. Flying at high altitudes, these aircraft provide not only airborne early warning capabilities, but also command and control functions.</p><p>Equipped with high-end sensors, these aircraft can carry out surveillance missions, coordinate strikes and intercepts, facilitate communications, and support search and rescue operations as needed.</p><p>The E-2C, which is being replaced by the newer E-2D, has been operational since the early 1970s.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 26683402},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:18:03","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:18:03","title":"A top White House coronavirus adviser is reportedly pushing the Trump administration to adopt a controversial 'herd immunity' strategy","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-adviser-is-pushing-white-house-to-adopt-herd-immunity-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d17747ffa48002894d221?format=jpeg\" alt=\"GettyImages-scott-atlas\" height=\"683\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Scott Atlas, a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution, speaks with President Donald Trump during a COVID-19 briefing on August 12.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jabin Botsford/The Washington Post via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>A recently hired pandemic adviser, Scott Atlas, is urging the White House to consider a \"herd immunity\" approach to combatting the coronavirus, <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-coronavirus-scott-atlas-herd-immunity/2020/08/30/925e68fe-e93b-11ea-970a-64c73a1c2392_story.html\">The Washington Post reported on Monday</a>.</li><li>The strategy is controversial because it would allow the disease to spread to most of the population in order to build resistance while also attempting to protect vulnerable groups such as older Americans.</li><li>Many health experts have said that such a strategy could cause hundreds of thousands of more deaths.</li><li>Shortly after The Post published its article, Atlas denied that the strategy was being proposed.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>A new coronavirus adviser is pushing the White House to adopt a \"herd immunity\" strategy that would allow the disease to spread through most of the population to build resistance, five sources <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-coronavirus-scott-atlas-herd-immunity/2020/08/30/925e68fe-e93b-11ea-970a-64c73a1c2392_story.html\">told The Washington Post</a> on Monday.</p><p>Scott Atlas, a healthcare policy fellow at Stanford University's conservative Hoover Institution think tank, joined the Trump administration <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/scott-atlas-new-medical-adviser-anti-lockdown-pro-schools-reopening-2020-8#:~:text=Scott%20Atlas%20as%20a%20coronavirus,not%20an%20infectious%2Ddiseases%20expert.\">earlier this month</a> as a top pandemic adviser. His expertise is in neuroradiology, and he \"does not have a background in infectious diseases or epidemiology,\" The Post said.</p><p>The Post's sources said Atlas had proposed that the US adopt Sweden's pandemic response, which relies on keeping the economy open so healthy people can build immunity to the disease through the spread of infection.</p><p>At the onset of the outbreak, the Nordic country decided against imposing strict lockdown measures &#8212; a far different approach from its European neighbors. Instead, it advised people to behave responsibly and told vulnerable populations, such as older people, to self-isolate if they had symptoms. The Post noted that Sweden now has among the highest COVID-19 infection and death rates in the world.</p><p>The approach has received mixed responses. Many public-health experts have described it as a reckless strategy that could result in hundreds of thousands more deaths. <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-08-31/who-special-envoy-heaps-praise-on-sweden-s-covid-strategy\">Others are considering</a> its feasibility as a long-term solution.</p><p>It's unclear exactly how many people would need to become infected to achieve herd immunity; estimates have ranged from 20% to 70% of the population, according to The Post.</p><p>The Post reported that Atlas had also suggested that an increased case count would not lead to more deaths if vulnerable people were protected, a claim that most infectious-disease experts strongly dispute. More than 25,000 people under age 65 have died of the virus in the US so far, the report said.</p><p>Before joining the coronavirus task force, Atlas regularly advocated reopening schools and businesses. He frequently appeared on Fox News to share his opinions, many of which aligned with those expressed by President Donald Trump's. Atlas now meets with Trump more than any other health official, The Post said.</p><p>\"When younger, healthier people get the disease, they don't have a problem with the disease,\" Atlas said in a Fox News interview in July. \"I'm not sure why that's so difficult for everyone to acknowledge.\"</p><p>Atlas has clashed with other officials, including Dr. Deborah Birx and Dr. Anthony Fauci, the US's top infectious-disease expert. A senior administration official told The Post that Atlas had positioned himself as an \"anti-Dr. Fauci.\"</p><p>Shortly after The Post published its report on Monday, Atlas released a statement denying any push for a herd-immunity strategy. \"There is no policy of the President or this administration of achieving herd immunity,\" he said. \"There never has been any such policy recommended to the President or to anyone else from me.\"</p><p>A White House representative also said there was no change to its approach.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 10:18:03","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:18:03","title":"How America's State Police Got Military Weapons","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-did-local-police-acquire-surplus-military-weapons-2020-8","description":"<div style=\"position:relative; overflow:hidden; padding-bottom:56.25%\">\n<iframe src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/5NknNtmO-jZbcmOYf.html\"\nwidth=\"100%\" height=\"100%\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"auto\" title=\"How America's State Police Got Military Weapons\"\nstyle=\"position:absolute;\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n</div><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>To date, the US has spent over $15.4 billion on the militarization of police.</li><li><strong>All of these weapons, vehicles, and equipment are acquired by the police through a military program called 1033.&#160;</strong></li><li>There are four major moments in history that enabled the creation of the 1033 Program: The Safe Streets Act of 1968, The Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1986, The National Defense Authorization Act of 1990, and The Patriot Act of 2000.</li></ul><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>Following is a transcription of the video:&#160;</p><pre>&#160;</pre><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> <br >After the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis on May 25, people protested in at least 140 cities across the nation. Here in Indiana, a protestor lost an eye from a tear gas container hitting him in the face.</p><p>In North Carolina, protesters were trapped by a cloud of tear gas on both ends of a street. In Kentucky, an officer attacked a newscaster and camera crew with pepper bullets.</p><p>And here in Detroit, police backed by armored vehicles marched down the streets. To date, the US has spent over $15 billion on the militarization of police.</p><p>All of these weapons, vehicles, and equipment are acquired by the police through a military program called 1033.</p><p>It's like eBay for cops with leftover war equipment, except everything is free and you only pay for shipping and handling. Up until 2017, police couldn't be in the program unless they used equipment within a year of receiving it.</p><p>So how did local police acquire all of these military weapons? And why do they even need them? To answer this question, we're going to examine four moments in history.</p><p><strong>Clip:</strong> From Dallas, Texas, the flash apparently official, President Kennedy died at 1 p.m. Central Standard Time.</p><p>Narrator: In the wake of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, President Lyndon B. Johnson and Congress signed the Safe Streets Act into law in June of 1968.</p><p>Through that act, in an effort to crack down on organized crime and gun violence, the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration was created.</p><p>LEAA guaranteed the distribution of federal money to fight organized crime. This funded what we know as SWAT, and it ensured SWAT received searchlights, emergency radios, bullhorns, nightsticks, body armor, face shields, and special weapons like M79 grenade launchers.</p><p>Prior to 1968, SWAT teams were used sparingly, only in volatile, high-risk situations like bank robberies or hostage situations. SWAT's first test as a militarized front came when the LAPD used a tank on loan from the California National Guard on the Southern California Black Panther Party.</p><p><strong>Clip:</strong> The intermittent warfare between the Black Panthers and police erupted today in Los Angeles. There, a group of them barricaded themselves in their headquarters and fought police with automatic weapons and hand grenades.</p><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> The US Department of State granted the LAPD authorization to use tear gas and sniper rifles. With national coverage, SWAT grew in popularity across the US and with other local law enforcement, creating a demand for military equipment.</p><p>LEAA's budget was a total of $7.5 billion, with a good portion going towards the militarization of US local law-enforcement agencies. After nearly a decade of extremely high budgets and spending, LEAA began to receive criticism because it had not shown success in decreasing crime rates.</p><p>On April 15, 1982, LEAA was abolished when Congress failed to fund it. But by that time, SWAT teams and their militaristic approach had already become the norm.</p><p>In 1986, Ronald Reagan's Anti-Drug Abuse Act expanded the use of no-knock or quick-knock warrants and assistance of the Air Force, Navy, and Marines in drug-related searches and seizures.</p><p>It allowed for members of SWAT to arrive at suspected locations of criminal activities and enter without knocking or announcing themselves, pointing guns at anyone inside.</p><p>They often used diversionary tactics like flash grenades, rendering their victims deaf and blind. In some cases, individuals believe they're experiencing a home invasion, to which they grab a gun. Like Jose Guerena, a former US Marine who was suspected of selling marijuana. What you're about to see and hear might upset you. He pulled a gun because he believed his home was being invaded, and the police shot him 60 times in seven seconds. No drugs were found.</p><p>In the early 1980s, there was on average about 3,000 recorded SWAT incidents per year. By the mid 1990s, that number grew to about 45,000 SWAT incidents per year. 75.9% were drug raids.</p><p>Of those raids, SWAT officers fired 342 times. They injured 61 and killed 139 citizens.</p><p>In 1989, George H. W. Bush signed the National Defense Authorization Act.</p><p>This act allowed for surplus DOD equipment from the Cold War to be transferred to US law enforcement. Sections 1207 and 1208 allowed for the following: \"the procurement of services and leasing of equipment\" and the transfer to federal and state agencies personal property, \"including small arms and ammunition.\"</p><p>And from those two sections, eight years later, the 1033 program was born. Under Bill Clinton's administration, the use of military surplus trade continued with the introduction of the Law Enforcement Support Office, LESO, which enacted US code title 10, section 2576a, also known as the 1033 program.</p><p>Much like National Defense Authorization Act 1208, the 1033 program expanded into other areas, including counterterrorism. This line states that surplus military equipment can be used for counter-drugs and counterterrorism efforts. This line states that surplus military equipment is free of charge minus shipping and handling.</p><p>Over $7.4 billion worth of property has been transferred since the program's inception. More than 8,000 law-enforcement agencies have enrolled. Items shipped include boots, radios, shields, M16 assault rifles, tanks, and silencers.</p><p>For every one qualified officer, one M1911 pistol, M16 rifle, or M14 rifle is allocated. For every three officers, a department can get a Humvee, and every law-enforcement agency has the ability if they apply to receive one MRAP.</p><p>And then, three days after 9/11, George W. Bush signed the Patriot Act.</p><p>It created a gray zone where law-enforcement agencies were able to perform more searches and seizures with access to delayed warrants, wiretaps, email, and web search surveillance, all in the name of fighting terrorism. But in reality, the liberties given to police were often used in drug-related cases. Only 1% of sneak and peek searches in 2010 were terrorism related. 76% were drug related.</p><p>And the United States' international actions also impacted law enforcement at home. As a result of an increase and then decrease of US operations in Iraq and Afghanistan over the years, there's been more military surplus equipment available to law enforcement, creating a spike in tactical items distributed by the 1033 program.</p><p>The Department of Defense does not provide training for law-enforcement agencies that receive military weapons. Instead, it's left to recipients to certify their own training each year. Because there is no federal mandate that police agencies report on SWAT operations, there's no real way to tell or quantify the effect of SWAT-related incidents.</p><p>In an effort to access the program's productivity and safety protocols, the Government Accountability Office created a fake federal agency. After acquiring more than 100 items worth over $1.2 million, the office recommended a process to implement fraud prevention in addition to a website that can track the equipment and the agencies it was sent to.</p><p>Prior to the investigation, there was very little record keeping and tracking of weapons after transfer. There were several instances where the agencies did not report lost weapons or disposal of excess equipment.</p><p><strong>Clip:</strong> And San Mateo and Napa counties were not the only departments in the nation to have lost equipment. About 200, in fact, have military equipment missing at this hour, and that includes, actually, some Humvees.</p><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> 184 state and local police departments were suspended from the 1033 program. In 2014, sparked by the murder of Michael Brown, civil unrest rolled through the streets of Ferguson, Missouri. Americans watching from home were shocked to see what looked like an army descending on such a small town.</p><p>On January 16, 2015, President Barack Obama issued Executive Order 13688.</p><p><strong>Barack Obama:</strong> You know, we've seen how militarized gear can sometimes give people a feeling like there's an occupying force as opposed to a force that's part of the community that's protecting them and serving them.</p><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> The order prohibited a list of equipment from being transferred to law enforcement through the 1033 program: tracked armored vehicles, weaponized aircraft, firearms of .50 caliber or higher, ammunition of .50 caliber or higher, grenade launchers, bayonets, camouflage uniforms. That executive order did not last long before being revoked in 2017 by President Donald Trump.</p><p><strong> Jeff Sessions:</strong> These restrictions that had been opposed went too far. We will not put superficial concerns above public safety.</p><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> Today, in 2020, in the wake of George Floyd's killing, protesters are being met with militarized police armed with 1033 program war surplus. No-knock warrants still result in the deaths of innocent citizens, like 26-year-old emergency medical technician Breonna Taylor.</p><p>Tear gas is still legal for domestic use on protesters but has been banned for use in war since 1993. And studies on rubber bullets, like the ones used here, show that 3% of those injured by rubber bullets died as a result of their injuries. 15.5% suffered permanent disabilities like eye loss, and nearly 50% of those who were struck on the head or neck were killed.</p><p>In the US, law enforcement kills over 900 people a year. Compare that to Norway, where there have been only four police-related killing since 2002.</p><p>Norway credits these numbers to its face-to-face community-building approach and believes it has created more trust between citizens and their police department. And we've seen similar changes stateside.</p><p>In 2001, a Cincinnati police officer shot and killed 19-year-old Timothy Thomas after he resisted arrest over minor crimes. After riots and protests, in fear of more unrest, the city began to reform its police department in collaboration with the Department of Justice.</p><p>They standardized procedures, making civilian-officer interactions more transparent. They also created a training program focused on mental health.</p><p>The reforms were met with pushback from city officials and a hostile police union, but the result was a 50% decrease in use of force from 2001 to 2007.</p><p>Data shows that building trust within the community may be a better solution to saving lives than using military weapons against them.</p><div new entry-level graphics card set to compete with Nvidia.&#160;</p><p>Over the weekend, AMD put the <a href=\"https://www.amd.com/en/products/graphics/amd-radeon-rx-5300\">Radeon RX 5300 GPU graphics card</a> on its website without any other announcement. The card is a competitor to <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/amd-stock-price-jumps-record-high-intel-delays-chips-earnings-2020-7-1029429636?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\">Nvidia's</a> GeForce GTX 1650 and undercuts it in price.&#160;</p><p>The under-the-radar launch comes after the semiconductor company beat analyst estimates when it reported better-than-expected earnings in July, boosted by <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/amd-q2-earnings-stock-price-leaps-earnings-win-strong-guidance-2020-7-1029445905#\">notebook and server processor sales.</a> In addition, AMD raised its current-quarter guidance, saying <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/amd-q2-earnings-stock-price-leaps-earnings-win-strong-guidance-2020-7-1029445905#\">it's confident it can meet strong demand.</a></p><p>AMD has rallied throughout 2020 &#8212; <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/amd-stock?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\">shares are up as much as 99% year-to-date</a>.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-investing-championship-strategy-matthew-caruso-contender-secret-to-return-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">US Investing Championship hopeful Matthew Caruso landed a 382% return in the first half of 2020. He shares the unique twist he's putting on a classic trading strategy &#8212; and 3 stocks he's holding right now.</a></em></p><p><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/amd-stock-price-jumps-record-high-intel-delays-chips-earnings-2020-7-1029429636?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\"><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d49787ffa48002894d328?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2020 08 31 at 3.02.29 PM\" height=\"894\" width=\"1130\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Markets Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></a></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a (Carmen Reinicke)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f4d41fb60bf1f002807984c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn72@2020_2/2020/09/01/02-18-16-958_b9760d8d29c3a6df.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4d49787ffa48002894d328?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn51@2020_2/2020/09/01/02-18-16-485_9a1c566c7d43be37.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?i=w4-u_H2qeAk:uWyIiOPNCjA:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn93@2020_4/2020/09/01/02-18-11-560_e4fb162cba8b73ae.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn80@2020_4/2020/09/01/02-18-14-200_99a57cc2511f53cd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=bcOpcFrp8Mo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn77@2020_4/2020/09/01/02-18-13-332_403f715e664a4d00.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?i=w4-u_H2qeAk:uWyIiOPNCjA:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn16@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-18-20-468_89f8ce831c5d4565.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=cGdyc7Q-1BI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn48@2020_2/2020/09/01/02-18-20-505_be4dce30169e75ab.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=QXVau8BzmBE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn89@2020_6/2020/09/01/02-18-22-732_c4d57f9dd1ff11a2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn71@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-18-24-178_0165ab2292566722.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=7Q72WNTAKBA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn61@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-18-14-887_b28aa1f69f1eb446.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider/~4/w4-u_H2qeAk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn31@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-18-12-902_47b955baa0268edb.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598926683398},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 10:18:03","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 10:18:03","title":"Delta and American drop change fees in their latest bid to woo wary passengers, less than 24 hours after United started the trend","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/the-big-3-us-airlines-drop-change-ancillary-fees-passengers-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d56357ffa48002894d387?format=jpeg\" alt=\"American Airlines and Delta Air Lines\" height=\"1636\" width=\"2182\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The three largest US airlines will be losing a chunk of tax-free revenue as they eliminate change fees on domestic flights.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thiago B Trevisan / Shutterstock.com</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>United, American, and Delta Air Lines are all doing away with change fees and select other optional fees.</li><li>United and American will also allow passengers to fly stand-by on earlier flights for free and offer other complimentary perks for elite status holders.</li><li>The US airline industry is still falling short of 1 million daily passengers with the summer only seeing a moderate increase in passengers compared to spring.&#160;</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>Less than 24 hours after United Airlines announced that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/united-airlines-ends-most-ticket-change-fees-not-basic-economy-2020-8\">it's eliminating change fees</a> for passengers, American Airlines and Delta Air Lines have followed suit. The country's two largest airlines each announced their latest attempts to win back pandemic-wary travelers within an hour of each other on Monday, marking the latest sign that the industry is struggling to return to normal following a <a href=\"https://www.tsa.gov/coronavirus/passenger-throughput\">disastrous summer</a>.</p><p>These airlines and many others started charging passengers who changed their plans in the early 2000s, part of a wave of ancillary fees for things like checking bags and priority boarding. The additional revenue from those add-ons is untaxed and can often be more lucrative than the fare itself.</p><p>But with no end in sight to the pandemic that has decimated travel demand and&#160;put the entire <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/american-airlines-furloughs-layoffs-coronavirus-2020-8\">industry in desperate financial straits</a>, airlines appear willing to sacrifice the most sacred of cash cows to win over those few folk willing to climb aboard.&#160;</p><p>Each airline, of course, has its own particular mix of incentives. United and American, for example, are also allowing customers to change to earlier flights on a stand-by basis for free.&#160;</p><p>Here's a breakdown of the changes each of the big three is making to its policies.</p><h2>United Airlines</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d64d27ffa48002894d407?format=jpeg\" alt=\"United Airlines 777\" height=\"3066\" width=\"4088\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>United was the first airline to announce the elimination of change fees for domestic flights.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Nicolas Economou/NurPhoto/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><a href=\"https://hub.united.com/2020-08-30-united-airlines-permanently-eliminates-change-fees-2647406401.html\">United became the first of the big three airlines to permanently get rid of change fees on Sunday</a>, dropping the $200 charge for domestic flight changes that includes travel to Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands. Passengers with most fares can make unlimited changes to the ticket and only pay the fare difference each time.&#160;</p><p>Basic economy will remain restrictive with United still not allowing changes to those with the fare but the airline's current travel waiver includes free changes for all tickets, basic economy and international included, booked until the end of the year.</p><p>Members of United's MileagePlus frequent flyer program will also be able to cancel their award tickets and have their miles redeposited for free if they cancel at least 30 days from departure. Elite status holders will also be able get on an earlier flight to their destination, if there's a seat available.&#160;</p><h2>American Airlines</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d64ea60bf1f0028079952?format=jpeg\" alt=\"American Airlines Airbus A319\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2220\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>American is not only removing change fees but also giving elite status holders perks when booking basic economy tickets.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Alex Tai/SOPA Images/LightRocket/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>American is removing change fees for domestic and certain international flights on all fares except basic economy.. Travelers flying domestically or between the US and Puerto Rico, the US Virgin Islands, Canada, Mexico, and the Caribbean will no longer be subject to the $200 fee for domestic flights and up to $750 fee for international, according to its <a href=\"https://www.aa.com/i18n/customer-service/support/optional-service-fees.jsp#ticketing\">fee schedule</a>.&#160;</p><p>The airline is also allowing customers the option to fly stand-by on earlier flights regardless of the fare or destination book, whether it be international or domestic, without paying a fee beginning on October 1. The charge for doing so was previously $75 for domestic flights, according to the airline's <a href=\"https://www.aa.com/i18n/plan-travel/extras/same-day-travel.jsp\">website</a>, with exceptions for international destinations.</p><p>United is also making basic economy less egalitarian, giving elite status holders expanded benefits when booking the fare. The airline's top frequent flyers will receive complimentary same-day confirmed flight changes and upgrades to first class and premium seats in economy when available.&#160;</p><p>In 2021, however, basic economy fares won't earn miles that can be used for accruing elite status.&#160;</p><h2>Delta Air Lines</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d64fc7ffa48002894d408?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Delta Air Lines Airbus A321\" height=\"2000\" width=\"2666\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Delta is doing the least out of the big three, just removing flight changes while making no other changes.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Bruce Bennett/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Delta <a href=\"https://news.delta.com/building-its-demonstrated-commitment-flexibility-customers-delta-eliminates-change-fees\">announced</a> on Monday the removal change fees for travelers in all classes except for basic economy on domestic flights including Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands. Customers formerly had to pay $200 to make changes to domestic tickets, according to the <a href=\"https://www.delta.com/us/en/change-cancel/change-flight\">airline</a>, including those to and from US territories in the Caribbean.</p><p>Basic economy or international fares will not be affected by the change, but Delta will allow free ticket changes for both under its existing waiver until the end of the year. The fare difference still applies when making a flight change and Delta has not said whether it will allow travelers to travel stand-by on earlier flights for free, as United and American are offering.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/the-big-3-us-airlines-drop-change-ancillary-fees-passengers-2020-8'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?a=uJ9JKlM1CkU:a2GvVHmV5ZI:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img derx27/cdn71@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-18-24-178_0165ab2292566722.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=7Q72WNTAKBA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn61@2020_3/2020/09/01/02-18-14-887_b28aa1f69f1eb446.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider/~4/uJ9JKlM1CkU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn80@2020_1/2020/09/01/02-18-17-575_c82c67313c4c1e9b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598926683404},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored\">The Sill</a></strong>, <strong><a href=\"https://shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=999&u=1088116&m=81579&urllink=www.leonandgeorge.com%2Feorge.com%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored\">Leon &#38; George</a></strong>, and <strong><a href=\"https://go.redirectingat.com/?id=35871X943606&url=https%3A%2F%2Fbloomscape.com%2Fm%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored\">Bloomscape</a></strong> are three popular online shops that sell and deliver a variety of indoor houseplants.</li><li>We've tested all three and found them to be convenient and reliable services, but they differ when it comes to shipping and return policies, plant care advice, and the types of accessories offered.&#160;</li><li>While <strong><a href=\"https://shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=999&u=1088116&m=79314&urllink=www.thesill.com%2Fesill.com%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow sponsored\">The Sill</a></strong> has the best giftable houseplants and plant care resources (on- and offline) and <strong><a href=\"https://shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=999&u=1088116&m=81579&urllink=www.leonandgeorge.com%2Feorge.com%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\">Leon &#38; George</a></strong> is the only service that ships to all 50 states, <strong><a href=\"https://go.redirectingat.com/?id=35871X943606&url=https%3A%2F%2Fbloomscape.com%2Fm%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\">Bloomscape</a></strong> offers the best overall shopping experience and the lowest shipping fees.</li><li>Read more: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-houseplants\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The easiest houseplants you can buy online, according to an urban farmer</a><section></section></li></ul><p>You're not just imagining it &#8212; everyone around you is <a href=\"https://www.gardencentermag.com/article/houseplant-comeback/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">suddenly interested in owning a houseplant</a>. Beautiful Instagram photos of sun-soaked, greenery-filled rooms, combined with the realization that taking care of a living thing is emotionally fulfilling, are making millennials buy up Swiss cheese-like <a href=\"https://go.redirectingat.com/?id=35871X943606&url=https%3A%2F%2Fbloomscape.com%2Fproduct%2Fmonstera%2Fa%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored\">Monstera plants</a> and resilient <a href=\"https://go.redirectingat.com/?id=35871X943606&url=https%3A%2F%2Fbloomscape.com%2Fproduct%2Fsansevieria%2Fa%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow sponsored\">snake plants</a> with renewed vigor.&#160;</p><p>The growth of cool, millennial-focused online shops is also playing a role.</p><p>Instead of going to a traditional nursery, you can browse and order attractive, low-maintenance plants online, plus receive the guidance and tips needed to take care of them properly. For anyone who lives in a metropolitan area or doesn't have access to a car, these online stores make it much easier to receive or gift plants without the hassle.&#160;</p><p><strong><a href=\"https://shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=999&u=1088116&m=79314&urllink=www.thesill.com%2Fesill.com%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow sponsored\">The Sill</a></strong>, <strong><a href=\"https://shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=999&u=1088116&m=81579&urllink=www.leonandgeorge.com%2Feorge.com%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\">Leon &#38; George</a></strong>, and <strong><a href=\"https://go.redirectingat.com/?id=35871X943606&url=https%3A%2F%2Fbloomscape.com%2Fm%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow sponsored\">Bloomscape</a>&#160;</strong>are a few of the more popular names in the houseplant delivery space. We tried each of them to send plants to ourselves and loved ones, and we were satisfied overall with their easy shopping experiences and reliable shipping processes.</p><p>But if you want to get into the nitty-gritty of how they differ in features like shipping and return policies, plant care advice, and types of accessories offered, we've laid out the facts below.&#160;</p><h2>Here are the similarities and differences between <strong><a href=\"https://shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=999&u=1088116&m=79314&urllink=www.thesill.com%2Fesill.com%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\">The Sill</a></strong>, <strong><a href=\"https://shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=999&u=1088116&m=81579&urllink=www.leonandgeorge.com%2Feorge.com%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\">Leon &#38; George</a></strong>, and <strong><a href=\"https://go.redirectingat.com/?id=35871X943606&url=https%3A%2F%2Fbloomscape.com%2Fm%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\">Bloomscape</a>:</strong></h2>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tTypes of plants sold\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e4ffca6fee23d1fb33ee0a6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Online House Plants Graphics Types of Plants\" height=\"562\" width=\"779\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Alyssa Powell/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>All three companies have a large variety of plants, from small and desk-friendly vines to tall and dramatic leafy species. Each site makes it easy to shop by size, pet friendliness (toxic vs. nontoxic), and the amount of light required.</p><p>None of the plants offered should be extremely difficult to take care of, but you'll find that the websites often have separate categories for low-maintenance plants, specifically. Even people who don't think they have green thumbs will feel comfortable shopping the stores.&#160;</p><p>We found each site's most unique and interesting plants:&#160;</p><h3><strong><a href=\"https://shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=999&#38;u=1088116&#38;m=79314&#38;urllink=www.thesill.com%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\">The Sill</a>:&#160;</strong></h3><div id=\"ProductCard_5f0cba904dca680b81073fac\" style=\"position:relative;
